case_vignette: A 3-year-old boy presents to the office with his mother. She states that her son seems weak and unwilling to walk. He only learned how to walk recently after a very notable delay. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all verbal and social milestones but he has a great deal of trouble with gross and fine motor skills. Past medical history is noncontributory. He takes a multivitamin every day. The mother states that some boys on her side of the family have had similar symptoms and worries that her son might have the same condition. Today, the boy’s vital signs include: blood pressure 110/65 mm Hg, heart rate 90/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the boy appears well developed and pleasant. He sits and listens and follows direction. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. He struggles to get up to a standing position after sitting on the floor. A genetic study is performed that reveals a significant deletion in the gene that codes for dystrophin.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I feel weak and I don't want to walk.
Have you experienced any numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation in your limbs?
No, I haven't felt any numbness or tingling.
How long have you been feeling this weakness and aversion to walking?
It's been happening for a while now.
Can you specify the duration? Days, weeks, months?
I can't specify the duration; it's just been for a while.
Have you experienced any changes in your mood or behavior recently?
No, my mood and behavior are normal.
Have you noticed any changes in your muscle tone or muscle bulk?
I have a lot of trouble moving around and using my muscles properly.
Do you have any difficulties with coordination or controlling your movements?
Yes, I struggle with both moving around and handling things with my hands.
Have you experienced any muscle twitching or involuntary movements?
No, I haven't had any muscle twitching or involuntary movements.
Do you have any difficulty with speaking, swallowing, or breathing?
No, I can speak, swallow, and breathe just fine.
Do you have a history of similar symptoms in your family?
Yes, some boys in my family have had similar symptoms.
What is your age and sex?
I'm a 3-year-old boy.
Based on the pattern of inheritance, have these family members been diagnosed with a specific condition?
I don't know the specific condition, but my mom is worried I might have the same thing as the other boys in the family.
Given the family history and symptoms, have you or the affected family members ever had genetic testing done?
Yes, a genetic test was done that showed something important was missing in my DNA.
Final Diagnosis: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 3-year-old boy visited the doctor with complaints of weakness and difficulty walking. He mentioned that the symptoms had been ongoing for a while but couldn't specify the duration. He also mentioned having trouble using his muscles properly and handling things with his hands. The boy reported that he has not experienced any numbness or tingling, muscle twitching, or involuntary movements. He can speak, swallow, and breathe without any issues. His mother is concerned because some boys in the family have had similar symptoms, and a genetic test revealed something important missing in his DNA.
trial_0.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Generalized weakness and reluctance to ambulate - requires further information for an accurate diagnosis.

I feel weak and I don't really want to walk.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 3-year-old boy.

No, I haven't had any recent illnesses or fevers.

No, I haven't fallen or injured myself recently.

No, I'm not experiencing any pain or differences when touched.

Yes, I get tired easily with activity.

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office feeling weak and having difficulty walking. He denies recent illnesses or fevers, as well as any recent falls or injuries. He also does not report experiencing any pain or differences in sensation when touched. There is a family history of similar symptoms in some boys. The boy also mentions that he gets tired easily with activity and has trouble moving around and holding onto things. His breathing and swallowing are normal.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I feel weak and don't really want to walk.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been having trouble with moving around and walking since I was a baby.
What is your current age?
I am 3 years old.
Are there any other symptoms such as muscle stiffness, seizures, or developmental delays?
I learned how to walk later than usual and have a lot of trouble with activities that use my big and small muscles.
Have you had any previous medical evaluations or tests for these symptoms? If yes, what were the findings?
No, my past medical history doesn't have anything to note.
Do your parents or any close family members have similar symptoms or have been diagnosed with any neurological conditions?
Some boys in my family have had symptoms like mine.
Have you or any members of your family had genetic testing done?
Yes, I just had a genetic test that found a big piece missing in a gene related to a muscle protein.
**Final Diagnosis:** Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.

trial_2.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Fatigue - nonspecific symptom (additional information required for precise diagnosis)

I feel weak and don't really want to walk.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been having trouble since I started trying to learn to walk.
